paragraphs.text: Immigration debate: What US could learn from Britain's David Cameron.
paragraphs.label: title

paragraphs.text: There is nothing like a little heat from a third political party to get the attention of career politicians who wish to stay in office
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Nigel Farage, leader of the upstart UK Independent Party (UKIP), has been turning up the heat on British Prime Minister David Cameron over the issue of migrants who come to the UK without jobs and immediately sign up for government benefits
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: The debate in Britain mirrors the one in the United States with one important exception
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: A treaty with the European Union requires Britain to accept migrants from all EU countries, no matter their employment status or health condition
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: As in America, this has put pressure on British taxpayers
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: many of whom think these migrants are taking jobs from British citizens and overburdening schools and the National Health Service
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: In a recent speech, Cameron proposed denying EU migrants access to certain welfare and other benefits for four years, including denial of a child allowance
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: unless
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: the immigrant children live with their parents in Britain
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: "Thus eliminating," writes the Wall Street Journal, "an incentive for immigrant families that try to arbitrage Britain's generous welfare state by raising children back home where costs are lower."
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: One parent lives in Britain to get the benefit, another stays in their home country with the children
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: who live on Britain's pound
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: No child benefit or tax credits paid for children living outside the UK, Cameron proposes
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: And he's right
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: He hopes such a move, if approved by Parliament
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: might deter thousands more unemployed immigrants from coming to Britain
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Cameron still must win approval from the other EU member nations
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: and
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: that is unlikely
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Poland has warned that it will vote against the proposal
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: unless
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: it also applies to British citizens who are unemployed and seeking benefits
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: German Chancellor Angela Merkel was reported to be "hopping mad" over Cameron's proposal
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: so
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: it remains doubtful if Cameron will get more than a short-term bump in his approval numbers ahead of next spring's anticipated elections
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Some conservatives within Cameron's Tory Party want Britain out of the EU, a position that goes back to the days of the late British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: who was skeptical of the EU from the start and feared the loss of British sovereignty and identity
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: The Washington Post recently reported "Net migration into (Britain) is now nearly at a post-recession high -- and about 50 percent greater as a proportion of population than it is in the United States."
paragraphs.label: statistics

paragraphs.text: The issue in the UK, as in America, is the character of the country
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: It isn't about resurgent "nativism,"
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: the label applied to some people who want to maintain the traditions, honor the history, save the English language and preserve other characteristics that make our countries attractive to residents and immigrants
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: No nation can long endure with unsecured borders
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: The Wall Street Journal recently suggested that Cameron might consider slashing the 20 percent value-added tax on consumption
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: "which disproportionately affects those with lower incomes."
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: For that matter the VAT could be slashed altogether to create an economic boom
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: but
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: that's a subject for another day
paragraphs.label: other

paragraphs.text: It isn' t xenophobic to suggest that immigrants ought to leave their political and other interests behind when they arrive in a new land
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: That's what immigrants to America did in the last century
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: They left their native countries because they believed America offered them and their children a better life
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: They intended to embrace all that is America, not hyphenate themselves into competing groups with dual loyalties
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Immigrants who wish to become fully British or fully American are the kind of people our countries want
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: What they don' t want are people who bring their agendas and seek to impose them on citizens
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: who, through military service and sacrifice, built something they wish to sustain for themselves and their posterity
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Is that too much to ask?
paragraphs.label: assumption
